content: On the copying, there may be a problem with the files. hard to detect. You have another option. You say the old computer stopped retrieving mail. I don't know the severity of that, but if interested, you could directly copy with windows the entire profile from old computer directly to new computer. If nothing else, that should ensure that the entire profile, bit for bit, was copied intact. If interested, here are the steps: - on new PC, copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to any other folder for safekeeping. - on old PC, copy that same folder to USB stick and from there to new PC (TB must NOT be running on eithr machine) - start TB on new PC and assess what is there. You should have exactly what was on old PC. If you can get it to read and write, you're done. - if you feel it was unsuccessful, you can exit TB and copy the backup you created back to same place.
creator: davidsk

Anything in GoogleDrive is a Bad idea

Bad idea - and won't work as you found out.

> Is there a way to avoid to have to copy again the updated msgFilterRules.dat on GoogleDrive and to re-create the symbolic link.

Sorry, there is not. As long as filters are only supported on a "per account" basis, you will face this limitation.

creator: rh30

content: Example: If filtering outgoing mail for janedoe@aol.com, you might select TO for first column, CONTAINS in second column and enough of the email id to be specific, such as janedoe@aol.com If you wanted to forward all mail FROM janedoe@aol.com to ryan@xyz.com, I would do this: FROM in column one, CONTAINS in column two, janedoe@aol.com in column three and for actions, I would show FORWARD TO ryan@xyz.com

content: Your latest post contradicts your first post. You want messages saved online, but removable on PC. To do that, you need POP, and set the account to not delete messages from server. Then, to delete (or recover) any messages, you would need to log onto online account. You can create POP accounts alongside the IMAP accounts and then delete the IMAP accounts afterwards.

content: My suggestion: unsubscribe from allmail folder. That is a folder Gmail maintains and there is no reason you need it. The 'allmail' folder, for example, includes messages that are in the trash. You will survive much better with gmail if you limit your subscriptions to inbox, sent, trash, etc. highlight the account, rightclick and on the subscribe pane, untick allmail.

content: This happens because the location is seen by TB as 'remote', and therefore subject to the remote images setting.
creator: davidsk

creator: RHall

content:
I do not allow any remote content and there are no exceptions.

If I go to gopher link you supplied and use: right click - 'save image as' and save on C drive in selected folder called gopher.gif In new Write use 'Insert' > 'Image' click on 'Choose' and select gopher File source says: file:///C:/Users/UserName/Desktop/hold/gopher.gif Note all foward slashes with filename Save as Draft and no problem - draft has a laughing gif

If I right click on the gopher gif and select 'Copy image' Go to Write and use right click Paste - I see the image, but save as draft and view draft - no go - it's blocked because it is a copy of external link which is not just an image because when I copied image it also included a load of remote content which you would not realise at time of copying.

I did a test - saved image as to folder on computer. Then right clicked on that downloaded saved file and chose copy In Write chose paste and sent to one of my email addresses. It did not arrive - discovered it in the webmail junk. Whilst gopher was live and kicking, the source code was a bit odd. filename expected it to be gopher.gif, In source view it says : Content-Type: image/gif; name="ovPZggKCnSJiI4WR.gif"

I did notice the saved gopher file properties said...This file came from another computer and might be blocked to help protect this computer


re :If the html is... img src="file://P:\TBsound\Laughing Gopher\gopher.gif" alt="Gopher"

If you are viewing the 'view source' code then you would not see that information in the html. I only see that info if I copy pasted eg gopher gif from the website and pasted into Write. It's basically a link to external file so it's considered remote. You may also see that if you chose not to attach the image to the message.

When you use Insert > Image - Choose select image file and also select checkbox 'Attach this image to the message' Normally you would see something like this in source

And at the end of email would be the attachment data of image with info to display inline.

So..Where is your P drive ? what exactly is the process you are using to insert that image gif ? What version of Thunderbird are you using ?

Are you using 'View' > 'Message Body as ' > Original HTML' ?

content: The msgFilterRules.dat file can be copied between accounts on the same or different computers. It's located in the account subfolder of Mail or ImapMail in the profile folder, e.g. ImapMail/imap.gmail.com. Copy the file with TB closed.
creator: sfhowes

content:
It determines when the filter is run.

1 - Getting new mail, run before Junk 16 - Manually run 32 - Getting new mail, run after Junk 64 - After sending 128 - Archiving 256 - Every 10 minutes

Add all the enabled run times to get "type".
creator: Toolworker
